text:
PAXTON HEHMEYER: Let me
introduce our two speakers if they need any introductions.

First, Andrew Ng is the
founder of deeplearning.ai. He's a managing general
partner at the AI Fund,

founder and CEO of LandingAI,
chairman and co-founder of Coursera, and an
adjunct professor at Stanford University.

And I believe he's teaching
classes right now here. As a pioneer in machine
learning and online education,

he's really changed a lot of
lives through his courses. I believe the number I have
is over 8 million people

have taken a machine
learning course or taken an AI class from him. He was also the founding lead
of the Google Brain team.

He served as VP and
chief scientist at Baidu. And he was also formerly the
director of the Stanford AI lab

here. In 2023, he was named
by Time magazine as one of the 100 most
influential people

in artificial intelligence. Right now, Dr. Ng focuses
his time primarily

on his entrepreneurial ventures,
looking for the best ways to accelerate responsible
AI practices in the larger

global economy. So thank you, Andrew,
for joining us. Mehran Sahami is the Tencent
chair of the computer science

department and the James
and Eleanor Chesebrough professor in the school
of engineering here at Stanford University.

As a professor here, he
is also the Bass fellow in undergraduate education
and previously served as the associate chair for
education in computer science.

He has been very involved
in designing and thinking about the computer science
education here at Stanford.

The last major changes in
it, Mehran spearheaded. Prior to joining the
Stanford faculty,

he was a senior
research scientist at Google with
research interests that include computer
science education,

artificial intelligence,
and ethics. I'm hoping we also get to
talk about that today, too. And finally, he did serve as
the co-chair of the ACM/IEEE-CS

joint task force on computer
science curricula in 2013, which created curricular
guidelines for college programs

in computer science at
an international level. He served as the chair of
the ACM Education Board

and an elected member
of the ACM Council and was appointed by the
California Governor Jerry Brown

to the state's computer science
strategic implementation plan advisory board. So thank you both for
joining us here today.

I can't think of two people
more knowledgeable and more interesting to talk to
about the topic before us.

ANDREW NG: Can I
just add something? I think you described Mehran by
lots of very impressive things. To people listening in
that may not have attended

Stanford, what you
may not know is Mehran is legendary
across Stanford campus.

And there's a huge
number of people that declared CS as a major. It's a very common story for
Stanford since coming to campus,

thinking of majoring in
something else and not sure what to major in, then they
take Mehran's class and decide,

you know what, I'm
going to be a CS major. So that's why. And I think over the years, I've
watched some of Mehran's videos

on intro programming
on YouTube and so on, and I've actually learned quite
a few teaching tips from him. So Mehran may be the best intro
to CS programming educator

in the world that
I know, and it's great to be chatting about this. [CHUCKLES] MEHRAN SAHAMI: Well,
it's wonderful to be chatting with you, Andrew.

It is a delight. You're far too kind. I mean, the way I think
about it is, students come to Stanford
because they want a chance to be able to learn
machine learning from you.

And the kinds of things you've
done in terms of democratizing education to the world through
Coursera and other platforms

are just incredible. So I very much
appreciate what you've done to change the
landscape of education,

both in computer science and
more broadly in the world. It's just incredible. ANDREW NG: Yeah, thank you. That's very kind of you.

PAXTON HEHMEYER:
That's exciting, yeah. And I should say again,
you have a chance to learn from both of them. I think, Mehran, you're
still teaching code in place,

usually every spring. So if you want to get a taste
of that intro to CS class,

Mehran teaches that. As I said, for both of them,
you can see their lecture videos are available all
over the place.

Stanford Online
has a lot of those. Stanford Online on YouTube. And Andrew, I'd say your machine
learning lectures on those

have over a million views
for just things like intro to linear algebra
for machine learning. So people are learning
a lot from both of you.

So thank you again. Before we jump into education,
though, I think maybe the place

to start right now, and I'll
start with you, Andrew, is with the recent advent of LLMs
or the recent widespread use

of LLMs, how have you
seen the profession of coding and software
development changing?

ANDREW NG: So AI is a
general-purpose technology being applied to lots of fields. We just saw,
actually today, they

announced the Nobel Prize in
chemistry awarded to what? Demis, and John, and
David Baker from UDub

in Google for applying AI
to chemistry and biology. And it was just yesterday
that the Physics Award

Nobel went to Jeff
Hinton and John Hopfield. So AI is having a huge impact
on lots of other fields.

But I find it
particularly exciting, as a software engineer or
developer myself, the impact

that it's having on our field. And maybe if I were to try
to synthesize all the stuff

happening, the most
exciting trend I'm seeing is things feel like they're
moving faster than ever in two

ways. One is experienced developers
are using GenAI in many ways. Software developers coding,
we do many different things

in our jobs and for a
huge range of things, from writing documentation to
generating code to debugging

code to writing test cases to
brainstorming architectures. For a lot of tasks of
professional software developers, GenAI
is really helping.

And then the other trend I
see exciting, maybe even more exciting, is helping to bring
a lot more people into software

engineering. You no longer need to
remember the details of the syntax of exactly
what weird incantation you

need to say in your code to make
a computer do that one thing. But tools are being used to let
many people learn a little bit

and, in a local fashion,
very quickly build compelling applications that
previously would have taken,

I don't know, many
months or even many years to learn enough to build. So bring a lot more
people to see us.

So it feels that
the whole field is moving much faster and a lot
more software is being shipped. PAXTON HEHMEYER: That's
really interesting.

So you're seeing on two levels. Both the very
experienced programmers using it to be more efficient to
get more done, but also people

without much
programming experience being able to write
sophisticated programs.

Mehran, can I hand
it over to you to follow-up on
that same question? But maybe from an academic
perspective or for when you're

sitting at Stanford, how do
you see generative AI changing

the kinds of research
or the things that you're seeing
happening at Stanford? MEHRAN SAHAMI: Sure. I mean, yeah, I
think to dovetail

on what Andrew was saying, one
of the things that's right on is thinking about
the industrial needs, how that transforms,
or the way we

think about that in
terms of education at the post-secondary level
and in college in general.

For example, a
little while back, I was involved in a
conversation where Kevin Scott, the CTO of
Microsoft, was there.

And one of the things
he was talking about is the widespread use of tools
like Copilot at Microsoft

to help their programmers
all become more productive across the company. But one of the
things he mentioned that was interesting
with respect to academia

is the expectation
in the industry that students coming
out of college, in the next one to
five-year time frame,

would have these kinds
of skills as part of their education
for developing code. So it's not just
something I think

that is a luxury of whether
or not we think about this, but it's really a necessity
in the toolbox of training

students at the collegiate
level to be effective software engineers. So that's how we think about it.

This is not a question
of if we do it. It's a question of
where and how we do it. And what I mean by
where and how is

what is the right level at
which we engage students with these tools as part of
their educational process,

and how does that
change what we think of as the traditional pipeline
or the traditional ways that we structure our
topics in computer science

education versus when's the
appropriate place for the tools? And I think that debate is
not yet entirely settled.

There's people looking
at different places where that might happen. Everywhere from it should
happen in the very first course

that students see
to, it's a tool that should be introduced
near the end when they're doing a large
project that they're

trying to wrap up
their degree with, and pretty much
everything in between. So, we're looking at
a few different models

for that at
Stanford, but I would say it's really just a
matter of when we do it and where we do it, not if we
do it because the [INAUDIBLE] is

that pervasive. ANDREW NG: Yeah, and one of
the most interesting things that I see across a lot of
academic institutions in CS

and other disciplines
is trying to forecast where the future work is going. Because in education,
first, we don't

want to train people
for yesterday's jobs. But in addition to training
people for today's jobs,

we also sometimes want
to make sure people have the skills to do the jobs
that will be around 2,

3, 4, 10, 20 years from now. And then, with the rapidly
evolving GenAI's, I

think it's clear. In the future, many developers--
maybe all developers should use GenAI because it'll
just be more productive than not

if you use it. But the tool chain is
evolving so rapidly that forecasting exactly what
are the fundamental skills

to teach that will be
generalizable and important for a long time versus the
things that may change quickly.

That's been challenging. As an example, I think VS
Code GitHub Copilot is great.

A fantastic tool, huge
productivity boost. And then we have
tools like Cursor that are very good at providing
the line-by-line changes

to the code and let
you approve or reject. And then was it just last
week or a couple of weeks ago, Open AI Canvas?

Again, really nice. Generate code and
then edit the codes.

And I find that effective
use of these tools, it does take a little bit of
training to know what to do.

When to trust the code or not. And maybe one thing that
I learned from friends

many months ago was if
I'm giving code that-- I used to be giving code out.

We read through the
function, figure out what this actually does. But it turns out, if
you type /*, a C++,

a pound sign into Phyton, have
GenAI read a comment for you, to document the code for you,
that saves you a lot of time.

Instead of reading all the
code, have it write a docstring or write a comment and
just read the comment. Because the GenAI
can read all the code

and describe it much faster
than I could read the whole function myself. But that's just
one tiny example.

I think there's so many tips and
tricks that having developers learn these processes
of using GenAI

feels like there's actually
a lot of work ahead. And the best practices
are still evolving, and the tool chains
are also evolving.

[INTERPOSING VOICES] PAXTON HEHMEYER: Oh,
go for it, Mehran. MEHRAN SAHAMI: No, no. I was just going
to say to dovetail on what Andrew said, because
I think he has great insights.

When he looks at
where the future is going for these things,
it's exactly the symbiosis that the tools are not just
giving the programmers code

to make them more productive. The tools are also teaching
the programmers about things. So when a programmer is
working with a new language,

for example, and wants to figure
out how to do something there and sees an example of it
that's generated by a tool,

it's not only about,
OK, now they're more productive because
they have that piece of code that they can insert in
their codebase somewhere,

but they're in fact learning
through literate coding, right? They're actually seeing the
stuff that it's produced, or they're asking, as
Andrew said, for comments

to be generated on it. And just the process of
using these tools actually becomes a learning experience
for the programmer.

So we actually get these two
effects there for productivity. One is the code
generation itself. The other is actually
the long-term learning

that's happening as a
result of using the tools. ANDREW NG: Actually,
that's a great point. A couple of months ago, I was
trying to code up an open source

thing myself. If it works, we'll release
this open source at some point, but it doesn't matter. But one of my friends, Lawrence
Moroney, who's ex-Google,

pointed out to me that one
of the ways that developers get a lot of benefit is
that there are these design

patterns for coding
that certainly I'm not that familiar with. Mehran may be more
familiar with them.

A couple of months ago, I
was working on an open source project, not yet released,
and I was trying to figure out

how to architect the code. And GPT-4 told me to use
a factory method, which

is a specific design pattern
in object-oriented programming that, candidly, I
don't use that often.

And I just hadn't thought of it. But with a mix of
GPT-4 and Claude 3.5,

I wound up architecting the code
using a factory method, which is actually much better than
the thing I was doing before.

And it reminded me of what
is the factory method design pattern. Those are interesting. You can search
online if you want.

It's an object-oriented
design pattern to instantiate objects without
knowing exactly what class

they'll be in. It was a much better
solution than I had coded up. And I think many
of these examples

that we use in GenAI as a
brainstorming partner will help us better understand pretty
core building blocks, especially

things that we may
not use every day. Oh, and syntax as well, right? There are libraries.

There are a lot of
libraries, like Pandas for manipulating data,
Streamlit for front end, for a lot of machine
learning applications.

Well, I love the
libraries, but I just can't remember the
syntax, frankly. I used to have to look up
documentation every single time.

But now, I don't even try that
hard to remember the syntax. I have GenAI write the code. And it feels like we're evolving
into this interesting paradigm

of almost generate and test,
which is a little bit dangerous. And I think best practices
are still evolving,

but the generate and verify
and maybe test paradigm is letting a lot of
teams get the software

written much faster. And sometimes high quality,
sometimes lower quality. Maybe that one's still
not yet determined.

PAXTON HEHMEYER:
I mean, those are both really, really interesting
points you're raising. And I guess,
Mehran, to come back

to you in terms of thinking
about the curriculum and where-- Andrew, you were saying a
lot of experienced developers

are using these tools. Well, they already have a
really strong foundation in computer science. So when you say, hey, you
should use the factory model,

you understand at some
level what that means and you can evaluate it.

Mehran, what are
you thinking about? What are the
foundational skills that will still be there
that a computer science majors will still need?

I mean, do you still
need to have probability? Do you still need to have
a basic algorithms class

and understand how to
build an algorithm? So I guess the question
to you, Mehran, is just

what are those foundational
skills that you still see that are really
important in order for you to be able to use
those tools, not in terms

of the interface with
the tools themselves, but to evaluate the work and to
be a thoughtful co-brainstormer

with those tools? MEHRAN SAHAMI: Sure. I mean, it's a great question. It does get to the point of
do we get a generating test

or generate and verify paradigm
with the generative AI tools? One of the things in the
thinking that we've been doing

is it's critical for
students to understand the code that's generated
for a number of reasons. One is to be able to verify
that code is operating correctly

more or less in terms of the
problem they're trying to solve. That in fact, the code is
appropriate for the problem

they're trying to solve. And as Andrew just
alluded to, when you think about different
ways of solving a problem,

they're efficiencies,
the architecture, how it kind of fits in,
having that level of taste in programming to
know what is better

and what is worse when
you're making your decisions around what you're building. And so you need to have some
experience with programming

before you can make
those decisions well. So, for example,
we would not count on students in the
very first course

to just generate the majority
of their code using these tools. And the first course,
what we want to do is we want to teach all the
foundational skills of thinking

about what are some of the
main concepts in programming, how do you put them together
in a particular language.

We teach Python right
now in our first course. But we've also taught
that course in C. We've taught it in Java.

We've taught in Pascal. Concepts all remain the
same, although the syntax change by language to language.

And what it tells
you is that there's these foundational concepts
in programming that are important for people to
know that live, in some sense,

parallel to the
syntax of the language that they're using to
solve their problem. And so those foundational
skills, oftentimes, we

think about in terms of
programming style as well. What does it mean to
take a large problem and break it up
into small pieces?

What does it mean to define
the interfaces between pieces of your code that are working
together to keep things modular,

to not scale complexity as
you're building the system? How do you actually mentally
model a piece of code execution

to be able to verify
that it works, or debug it, or
find issues in it? Those are all
foundational skills.

We think, certainly
in the first course and probably in
the second course, are things that are not going
to change a lot because students

need to learn them. When you move beyond
that and say, OK, now you have those skills, now
you can have someone present a piece of code to you
and be able to go through it,

and really dissect
it, and figure out, are there better
ways of doing this? Can I debug the code? Whether that code was
generated by a human being

or by a machine, in some sense,
it doesn't really matter. You just need to bring
those skills to bear to be able to think
about how you understand

that piece of code
in a better way and its role in a larger system
that you're architecting. So that could be the
third course, all the way

through the nth course. Or the nth course is
like a senior project or whatever that
students do at the end of their undergraduate degree
or a capstone, let's say,

that they do in high school. So we think that there's lots
of touch points along the way, but you need to have a
solid foundation on things.

That's probably not
going to change a lot for the first couple courses. But then, beyond that, you
have a lot of room for.

PAXTON HEHMEYER:
Andrew, is there anything you'd want
to add to that? Anything you've seen in
your own practice or people you've worked with in terms
of those foundational skills

that you think are going to-- yeah, that are absolutely
essential for just evaluating the products
of generative AI

in terms of coding? ANDREW NG: Yeah, so
I agree with Mehran. A lot of the core
foundational building blocks

are still important. Maybe let me illustrate
this with one example why.

Maybe someday we'll have
some wonderful AGI that could do anything a human can. And then we don't need to think
about these things ourselves.

But that seems really far away. But I think one
of the bottlenecks of getting AI systems today
to be more intelligent

or make better decisions or
whatever is that there's still often lacking a lot of context
about why we do certain things.

And humans have a lot of context
that, for whatever reason, is it data plumbing or whatever? But for lots of
reasons, AI today

is just missing
a lot of context.  Maybe another example. I was coding up some
things a couple months ago.

It was really slow. I decided to implement a cache. I've forgotten the syntax for
how to call a certain Python

module, cache, or whatever. GenAI do that for me. But I reflected,
I needed to know that there's such thing as a
cache, cache or memorization,

so I could get the AI
system to just write the code for me, which it did
perfectly to use the cache.

But I had not known that
there was such a thing as a cache, which is a
concept taught in intro to CS

types of courses. I wouldn't have
gotten that job done. And I think the reason
that I, in that example,

the software was too slow. And I don't know how much
plumbing in data infra would have needed to give the
GenAI the context of what's

important about
the applications. But that reasoning draw
that conclusion itself. And then second, I knew
we had access to this.

I knew space wasn't a problem. So I could make a
really quick decision. Let's just see if we can
implement this with a cache.

But the context that went
into that decision of let's do this and not that, to
build a cache, as well as some other thing, that's
actually a complicated decision.

Maybe someday AI has enough
context, enough background knowledge about what are
the resources, what's

important to reason through
and make these decisions. Then maybe humans can step back
from those high-level decisions.

But good software engineers,
good software architects have an amazingly
broad span of context

about what's possible in
what they're trying to do. And until we manage to
digitize all that context

and get in the GenAI and
also improve reasoning, I think we just need humans to
do that for quite a long time.

PAXTON HEHMEYER:
It's interesting. Mehran, and building
on that, let's say it's now 5, 10
years in the future.

You're here. You're overseeing
the CS curriculum. You're looking at students. What are you going to
be sad that they're

no longer able to do? I mean, there's always this fear
of some level of de-skilling

that might come along with it. And maybe that's not bad. Maybe that's good. If you're not doing that,
you're doing something else.

And I think in particular, there
was an interesting comment, and maybe this is a little
bit tangential to this,

by one of your former
colleagues, Daphne Koller, in a recent talk she was
giving where she said,

in terms of machine learning
that one of the things that had fallen by the wayside
with recent advances is the ability of
researchers to really

think deeply about how to map a
particular problem onto a model. How to map it onto a
machine learning model.

Because right now, you can
just throw data at a problem. But especially as you move
into more data-sparse areas

like physical systems
or machine learning, or sorry, autonomous vehicles,
those kinds of things,

you're still going
to really need to have that skill
to think deeply about how to map a problem onto
a particular machine learning

model. So that's my way
of saying, yeah, what are you going to lament? What do you think is going
to be lost in this, again,

for better or for worse,
in the next 5 to 10 years? MEHRAN SAHAMI: Right. And I think it's a good point.

For me personally, I should
think, to lay the context, I see a lot more
upside than downside.

And so what I would
say by that is-- when I was an
undergrad, we were all required, everyone, in
the computer science

program at Stanford to take
a course on machine language, right? Because that's just one of the
things you need in terms of,

you're going to speed
up particular things in the machine. And I thought it was
an interesting course. It was a fun course.

I do not lament that students
don't have to learn, right? We have progressed to
a place where students can think about
higher-level issues

and have that stuff
well optimized for them. So I don't lament that loss.

What I potentially lament is as
these systems get architected and built out, our students,
do they have the taste,

like Andrew mentioned,
to think about what are some of the things that
can actually-- a concept that can have a big
impact on their code?

That's what I hope
doesn't go away. Caching. A big concept that can have
a big impact on your code. Parallelization. Concepts that can have a
big impact on your code.

So these are the kinds of
things that I don't want people to become complacent to
say that everything's going to get handled for you.

The machines are
getting smarter. So I can envision a world
in which we'll basically move higher and higher up
the food chain in terms

of what we need to worry about. But I hope we don't lose sight. I hope there's always
people who think

about these foundational
concepts of hey, we could think about
this low-level thing in a different way, and that
might speed up everything that

happens higher in the stack. But I think the reality
is we don't need everyone to be doing that. There needs to be some people
that specialize in that.

And everyone else can benefit
from the things they do. It reminds me of this
example from Facebook

when it was still called
Facebook rather than Meta, as they were using PHP as
their programming language. They had a team
that just worried

about optimizing the
implementation they had on [INAUDIBLE]. And the interesting
thing is, any gains

that they got on performance,
everyone else in the company got the benefit
because they were just sitting on top of that stack.

And there was actually times-- I remember, Mike Schrepfer was
their CTO at the time saying, there were times when
they were thinking

about machine provisioning
quarter to quarter in terms of what their
projected needs would be, and their projected
needs would actually

go down in some sense
from what they already had because the efficiency gains
were so high that now, they

had a whole bunch of
machines available to them that were just essentially being
used for executing [INAUDIBLE]

So I think that's
potentially a world we move closer and closer to
as these tools get smarter

and smarter in some sense. But I don't want to lose the
fact that there are still people who are working at a
very low layer who are helping

create these optimizations
for everyone who's benefiting on top. If we're all sitting
on top, then eventually

we're going to lose that
optimization level underneath. PAXTON HEHMEYER: Andrew,
is there anything--

I have a follow-up
question for you. But anything you'd want to
add to what Mehran just said? ANDREW NG: Yeah. Well, Mehran put it very well.

One of the reasons CS
has made so much progress is with multiple
layers of abstraction.

From quantum physics to
transistors to semiconductors, assembly language to low-level,
high-level programming

languages. And in AI, we then have learning
algorithms, foundation models, applications. So it's a huge stack.

And I think having people--
and today, we still have people worrying about
quantum physics and the physics

of transistors, which is great. So people working on
all layers of the stack. One thing I've
learned is that when

there's a new technology,
then the ability to peer a couple of
layers lower is helpful.

So for example, with
large language models right now, which are
relatively immature, there are orchestration
layers that help people manage

the workload built using LLMs. But because it's still not
really mature technology, if you can break through
that abstraction layer

to go a layer deeper, you can
often get a better performance. But assembly language may be one
example where once upon a time,

ordinary mortals could
write assembly code better than a compiler. But honestly, today, I would not
want to compete with a compiler

in optimizing any code anymore. Some people can. But not me, right? And so we just operate only
a high level of abstraction.

And so I think just
dynamic building up layers of abstraction. And sometimes, you do want to
teach people a couple of layers

deeper so they can-- maybe one example. Most of the time, I don't
worry about my sort function.

I just call someone else's
library to sort something, and it works just fine. But it turns out, if
you're sorting really

large files that
need to swap to disk because you're not getting
memory, then understanding how sorting actually
works, it could actually

help you think through how
to architect a sorting thing. That's a corner case. Mostly, I don't
worry about sorting.

But there are some
corner cases of really, really massive data
sets where understanding how sorting actually works still
drives better performance today.

So one thing about computer
science departments is, I think, as the
layers of abstraction move

up, to keep on
moving up the stack and then being
thoughtful about how deep to ask everyone to still go.

Because sometimes it's
useful and sometimes it becomes less useful. PAXTON HEHMEYER: That's
really interesting.

I want to come back to
these layers of abstraction. But Andrew, just staying with
you in a follow-up there.

When talking about
how AI will impact, in particular, generative AI
will impact jobs, what I think

is a really useful framing, as
you say, don't think about jobs, think about the tasks
that you're doing and how that will
influence the tasks.

And I was hoping you could talk
a little bit more about that. And in particular, what I'm
hearing from both of you

is, there may be a world
where, in a few years, maybe I'm doing a
lot of the things where I'm trying to
find a computer science

student at Stanford
to do, hey, can you write a web scraper for
me to find these things and compare our site
to Stanford's, make

sure we're not out of sync? Maybe in the
future, that program is just now offloaded
to someone who

we worry about AI

I find it more useful. Really, Eric taught me this. Take a job, break it
down to the tasks, see what tasks AI can
automate or augment.

And one thing I'd
love to see is-- I really want to encourage

to learn to code. I think it'd be worthwhile
for definitely many knowledge workers, maybe
pretty much everyone.

Well, one society wondered

There was a view that,
